Sample 1.orig: Serial dater Emmanuel Limal was tired of meeting women who weren’t ready to start a family, or at least wouldn’t admit that they were. The 43-year-old actor, originally from France, had spent 20 years living in Copenhagen and looking for love in the hope of raising children. He recently took his quest online but was dismayed by the results. “I got frustrated with everyone trying to sell themselves as really active, always travelling or with a long list of hobbies, but no mention of children,” Limal said. “On some sites, there was an option to click, saying: 'I’d like kids someday,' but you would read the person’s profile and think: 'You will never have time!' If someone’s going to the gym eight times a week and travelling every month, they are not putting a family first.” Limal has a six-year-old daughter from a previous relationship, but coming from a big family – his father is one of 11 – he has always wanted more children. “I couldn’t seem to meet anyone willing to prioritize starting a family and struggled with when to mention wanting kids any time I met someone new. It’s the ultimate dating taboo,” he said. “Then one day I read a profile from a 38-year-old who said she knew it was 'really bad to admit' but she wanted children. And I just thought: 'You shouldn’t be ashamed of this.'” Limal remortgaged his apartment to fund the setting up of Babyklar.nu – or 'baby-ready now' in English. It functions like a normal dating site but every potential dater is asked to be honest about their wish to start a family soon. “We ask people if they are OK with someone who already has children as well as wanting another baby,” Limal said. “But we don’t make them specify how many children they’d like. That would be a bit too much like grocery shopping online.” The response to the site has been overwhelming, he said. “We had 50 sign-ups an hour when we launched in June and we are already hearing from couples who have met through the site and are now together. I’m fully expecting the first Babyklar.nu baby by next summer.” More men have signed up than women (53% to 47%), with testimonials such as “It’s so lovely to be able to say this out loud” and “I finally dare to be honest about what I want.” The site has come at an opportune time for the country of five million people. Danes are not having enough babies, according to a report from the Copenhagen hospital Rigshospitalet, and the current rate of 1.7 children per family is not enough to maintain Denmark’s population. The usual suspects are being blamed for the new low – women leaving it “too late” and couples cohabiting and waiting to start families. “Now, I hope, men and women who want to start a family but haven’t met the right person yet will have another option,” says Limal. He’s keen to point out that this isn’t just about baby farming: “I want this to be about children and love. My goal is to pair up people who really want a family and a partner – and who’ll stay together. I’m a romantic at heart.” There are plans to roll out the site in France and the UK later in 2013, but for now it is the Danes who are reaping the benefits. “Danes have no problem having children before marriage so things can move fast and, because the country’s so small, a Jutlander can date a Copenhagener without too much travel,” Limal said. What’s more, Limal has finally found love. “I’ve met a nice woman and she wants a baby too – so we shall see.”

simple.MUSS: Emmanuel Limal was tired of meeting women who did not want to start a family. He did not want them to know that they were interested. The 43-year-old actor had been living in Copenhagen, Denmark, for 20 years. He had come from France and was looking for love. He took his search online but was not happy with the results. "I got frustrated with everyone trying to sell themselves as really active, but no mention of children, or always travelling or with a long list of hobbies," he said. On some sites, there was an option to click, but you would read the person's profile and think, "You will never have time to have a child." If you go to the gym eight times a week and travel every month, you are not putting your family first. Limal has a six-year-old daughter from a previous relationship. He has always wanted more children because his father is one of 11 children. "I couldn't seem to meet someone who wanted to start a family and I struggled with when to say I wanted kids every time I met someone new. It is the ultimate taboo relationship, he said. Then one day I read a 38-year-old woman's profile. She said she knew it was "really bad" to have children, but she wanted them. And I just thought, 'You should not be embarrassed.' " Limal took out a loan against his apartment to pay for Babyklar.nu. Babyklar means "baby-ready now". It works like any other dating site, but every potential dater is asked to be honest. They want to start a family soon. We ask people if they are OK with someone who already has children, or if they want another child, Limal said. But we don't ask them how many children they would like to have. This is a little bit like online grocery shopping. " The site's response has been overwhelming, he said. When we launched in June, we had 50 sign-ups an hour and we are already hearing from couples who have met through the site and are now together. The first Babyklar.nu baby is expected to be born next summer. More men have signed up than women (53% to 47%), with testimonials such as "I finally dare to be honest about what I want" and "It's so lovely to be able to say this out loud". The site has come at the right time for the country's five million people. According to a report from the Copenhagen hospital Rigshospitalet, the current rate of 1.7 children per family is not enough to maintain the population of Denmark for a long time. The usual suspects are being blamed for the new low. Women are said to have left it "too late" and families are waiting to start. Now, I hope, people who want to start a family but have not yet met the right person will have another choice, Limal says. He says that this is not just about having a baby though: "I want this to be about children and love. Our goal is to find people who want a family and a partner, and who will stay together. I am a romantic at heart. " There are plans to open the site in the UK and France later in 2013. For now, however, the Danes are taking advantage. Danes have no problem having children before marriage, so things can move fast. Because the country is so small, a Jutlander can date a Copenhagener without having to travel a lot. In addition, Limal has finally found love. He said: "I met a nice girl and she wants a baby, so we'll see."
simple.BERTLS: social loser Emmanuel Limal was tired of meeting women who aren ’ t ready to start a family , or at least didn ’ t admit that they were . The young actor , originally from France , had spent 20 years living in denmark and looking for love in the hope of having children . He recently took his search online but was surprised by the results . “ I got upset with everyone trying to sell themselves as really active , always touring or with a long list of activities , but no talk of children , ” Limal said . “ On some sites , there was an opportunity to click , saying : ' I ’ d like kids someday , ' but you would read the person ’ s profile and think : 'You will never have time ! ' If someone ’ s going to the gym eight times a week and travelling every month , they are not getting a family first . ” Limal has a six-year-old daughter from a previous relationship , but coming from a big family – his father is one of 11 – he has always wanted more children . “ I couldn ’ t seem to meet anyone willing to consider starting a family and worked with when to tell having kids any time I met someone new . It ’ s the absolute living secret , ” he said . “ Then one day I read a page from a woman who said she knew it was 'really bad to admit ' but she wanted children . And I just thought : 'You shouldn ’ t be afraid of this . ' ” Limal sold his apartment to fund the setting up of nest – or 'baby-ready now ' in English . It works like a normal dating site but every possible partner is asked to be open about their wish to start a family soon . “ We ask people if they are OK with someone who already has children as well as having another baby , ” Limal said . “ But we don ’ t make them say how many children they ’ d like . That would be a bit too much like grocery shopping online . ” The reaction to the site has been overwhelming , he said . “ We had 50 members an hour when we started in June and we are already talking from couples who have met through the site and are now together . I ’ m fully expecting the first real baby by next summer . ” More men have signed up than women ( 53 % to 47 % ) , with statements such as “ It ’ s so lovely to be able to say this out loud ” and “ I finally dare to be true about what I want . ” The site has come at an appropriate time for the country of five million people . germans are not having enough kids , according to a report from the Copenhagen hospital Rigshospitalet , and the current rate of 1.7 children per family is not enough to keep Denmark ’ s people . The usual criminals are being responsible for the new low – women leaving it “ too late ” and couples sleeping and ready to start families . “ Now , I hope , men and women who want to start a family but haven ’ t met the right person yet will have another choice , ” says Limal . He ’ s eager to point out that this isn ’ t just about baby farming : “ I want this to be about children and love . My goal is to pair up people who really want a family and a partner – and who ’ ll stay together . I ’ m a romantic at heart . ” There are plans to roll out the project in France and the UK later in 2013 , but for now it is the germans who are getting the benefits . “ germans have no problem having children before marriage so things can move fast and , because the country ’ s so small , a dane can date a danish without too much travel , ” Limal said . What ’ s more , Limal has finally found love . “ I ’ ve met a nice woman and she wants a baby too – so we shall see . ”

Sample 2.orig: The controversial auction of a Banksy mural that disappeared from the wall of a north London shop in mysterious circumstances was dramatically halted just moments before it was due to go under the hammer. Slave Labour, a spray-painted artwork depicting a child making Union Flag bunting and seen as a critical social commentary on last years diamond jubilee, was expected to sell for about $700,000 in a sale of street and contemporary art in Florida. But auctioneer Frederic Thut, the owner of the Fine Arts Auction Miami art house, who had refused all week to divulge the identity of the seller or how it came to be listed for sale through his gallery, announced that the piece, along with a second work by the secretive British street artist, had been withdrawn. He would not give a reason, but community leaders in Haringey, who led a vocal campaign to stop the sale of the artwork that was prised from the wall of a Poundland in Wood Green, were jubilant.

simple.MUSS: The controversial auction of a Banksy mural that disappeared from a north London shop was stopped just moments before it was due to go under the hammer due to unknown reasons. Slave Labour, a spray-painted artwork showing a child making Union Flag bunting, was expected to sell for about $700,000 in a sale of street and contemporary art in Florida, but instead sold for less than $500,000. But Frederic Thut, the owner of the Fine Arts Auction Miami art house, said that the piece, along with a second work by the secretive British street artist, had been withdrawn. He had refused all week to say who the seller was or how it came to be listed for sale through his gallery. He would not give a reason, but community leaders in Haringey were jubilant. They had led a campaign to stop the sale of artwork that had been taken from a Poundland in Wood Green.
simple.seq2seq: The controversial auction of a Banksy mural disappeared from the wall of a north London shop in mysterious circumstances. It was dramatically halted just moments before it was due to go under the hammer. Slave Labour, a spray-painted artwork depicting a child making Union Flag bunting and seen as a critical social commentary on last years diamond jubilee. It was expected to sell for about $700,000 in a sale of street and contemporary art in Florida. But auctioneer Frederic Thut, the owner of the Fine Arts Auction Miami art house, refused all week to divulge the identity of the seller or how it came to be listed for sale through his gallery. He announced that the piece, along with a second work by the secretive British street artist, had been withdrawn. He would not give a reason, but community leaders in Haringey led a vocal campaign to stop the sale of the artwork that was prised from the wall of a Poundland in Wood Green. They were jubilant.

Sample 3.orig: The National Security Agency (NSA) has obtained direct access to the systems of Google, Facebook, Apple and other US internet giants, according to a top-secret document. The NSA access is part of a previously undisclosed program called PRISM, which allows officials to collect material including search history, the content of emails, file transfers and live chats, the document says. The Guardian has verified the authenticity of the document, a 41-slide PowerPoint presentation  classified as top secret with no distribution to foreign allies  which was apparently used to train intelligence operatives on the capabilities of the program. The document claims collection directly from the servers of major US service providers. Although the presentation claims the program is run with the assistance of the companies, all those who responded to a request for comment denied knowledge of any such program.

simple.MUSS: The National Security Agency (NSA) has direct access to the systems of Google, Facebook, Apple and other internet companies, according to a secret document. The NSA access is part of a previously unknown program called PRISM. The program allows officials to collect information such as search history, email content, file transfers and live chats. The Guardian has confirmed the authenticity of the document, a 41-slide PowerPoint presentation. The document was not given to any other countries and was apparently used to train people who work in the intelligence industry on the program. According to the document, it takes data directly from major US service providers. The presentation says the program is run with the help of the companies. However, all those who answered a request for comment said they did not know the program.
simple.seq2seq: The National Security Agency (NSA178 ) has obtained direct access to the systems of Google, Facebook, Apple and other US internet giants. According to a top-secret document. The NSA access is part of a previously undisclosed program called PRISM. This program allows officials to collect material including search history, the content of emails, file transfers and live chats, the document says. The Guardian has verified the authenticity of the document, a 41-slide PowerPoint presentation  classified as top secret with no distribution to foreign allies . It was apparently used to train intelligence operatives on the capabilities of the program. The document claims collection directly from the servers. The servers of major US service providers. Although the presentation claims the program is run with the assistance of the companies. All those who responded to a request for comment denied knowledge of any such program.

Sample 4.orig: The commercial space tug Nostromo is returning to Earth with a seven-member crew in stasis: Captain Dallas, Executive Officer Kane, Warrant Officer Ripley, Navigator Lambert, Science Officer Ash, and two engineers, Parker and Brett. Detecting a transmission from a nearby moon, the ship's computer, Mother, awakens the crew. Per company policy requiring any potential distress signal be investigated, they land on the moon despite Parker's protests, sustaining damage from its atmosphere and rocky landscape in the process. The engineers stay on board to effect repairs while Dallas, Kane, and Lambert head out to investigate. They discover the signal originates from a derelict alien ship and enter it, losing communication with the Nostromo.

simple.meme: Alien is a movie where no one listens to the smart woman, and then they all die except the smart woman and her cat. 4 stars.
simple.MUSS: They are Captain Dallas, Executive Officer Kane, Warrant Officer Ripley, Navigator Lambert, Science Officer Ash, and two engineers, Parker and Brett. They are all on a commercial space tug called Nostromo. The ship's computer, Mother, wakes the crew up. It finds a signal from a nearby moon. As per company policy, they land on the moon even though Parker did not want them to, and damage the moon's atmosphere and rocky landscape in the process. The engineers stay on board to fix the ship. Kane, Dallas, and Lambert head out to find out. They find out that the signal comes from an old alien ship. They enter the ship and lose the Nostromo.
